titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Miscellaneous Letters and Documents Collection, 1824-2010
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library MS-33
titlepage.publisher: Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library

archdesc.runner: Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library, University of Virginia
did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Letters and Documents Collection, 1824-2010

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Miscellaneous Letters and Documents Collection, Accession #MS-33, Historical Collections, Claude Moore Health Sciences Library, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection is a compilation of letters and documents donated by different people over time to Historical Collections.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The letters and documents are a miscellaneous collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The scope and content of the documents are diverse. This collection includes papers on the history of the Paul Goodloe McIntire Memorial Clinic, the development of the Otolaryngology Program at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, and women medical students at UVA in the 1920s. Also included are a letter from Rene Laennec, inventor of the stethoscope, and another from Carl Rokitansky, a famous pathologist. There is a series of letters from George W. Banks, a medical student in the 1890s; 1831 lecture notes on cholera and its treatment; examinations by the West Virginia Board of Examiners for Registered Nurses from the 1920s; the early 1900s daybook of Dr. J. E. Copeland; William P. Braxton's lecture cards from medical courses at the University of Pennsylvania in the 1830s; an account book kept by [Dr.?] Robert Gamble in the 1830s; two 19th century recipe books; and documents concerning Nuzhet O. Atuk and the beginning of hemodialysis at the University of Virginia Hospital.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The arrangement of the documents is dependent upon the time of their donation and processing.

did.unittitle: "The Capsule," "Nurse Please!" Pictured by Jean McConnell, 1944-45
did.physdesc: 1 TD mimeographed 6pp., 1 book with AN, 2 B&W photos 2.75" x 4.5", 2 AN

scopecontent.p: "The Capsule" is a University of Virginia newsletter for nurses. "Nurse Please!" was the property of Barbara Hughes Moore and includes drawings with the names of people from UVa written in. The photos are of unidentified people but included in the folder are 2 pieces of paper with the names of Barbara Hughes Moore and Ellen Stout.

did.unittitle: "History of the Paul Goodloe McIntire Memorial Clinic at the University of Virginia Hospital" by Zula Mae Baber, 1949 December
did.physdesc: 2 TMs with AN 32pp., 1 TD with AN 1p. 1 card, 1 card in folder

scopecontent.p: The McIntire Memorial Clinic was the first tumour clinic in Virginia, and the precursor of the University's present Cancer Center.

did.unittitle: "Development of the Otolaryngology Program at The University of Virginia School of Medicine" by Robert W. Cantrell, M.D., 1980 January 13

scopecontent.p: This paper was presented at the 17th Annual Meeting of the Advisory Committee, University of Virginia Medical Alumni. Cantrell mentions, among others, Drs. Fletcher Woodward, G. Slaughter Fitz-Hugh, Robert A. Jahrsdoerfer, Michael Johns, W. Copley McLean, Edwin Rubel, and Roger Ruth.

did.unittitle: "The Out Patient Department, University of Virginia Hospital Charlottesville Virginia," 1950
"The Notebook of Robley Dunglison, Student of Clinical Medicine in Edinburgh, 1815-1816" by Mary Jeanne A. Jones and Chalmers L. Gemmill, 1967

scopecontent.p: Article is reprinted from "Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Sciences"

did.unittitle: Letters from Nell Fuller to Myrl Ebert and from Nell Fuller to Minnie Orfanos, 1973 November 12, 29

scopecontent.p: Nell Fuller was Head of Technical Services at the Health Sciences Library.

did.unittitle: Letter from Frank L. Hereford to Jesse L. Fowler with enclosed resolution, 1976 August 20

scopecontent.p: The resolution concerns the establishment of the Walter Merritt Seward Chair of Family Practice at UVa.

did.unittitle: Letter from George R. Minor to Mr. Kincaid, 1956 February 16

scopecontent.p: Minor requests contributions for a portrait of Dr. "Ned" Lehman.

did.unittitle: Exam in Histology (Tuttle), 1897 March 18

scopecontent.p: This exam was found inserted in John T. Thornton's copy of "Notes on Anatomy" (1893) by William B. Towles. "Tuttle" is Albert H. Tuttle, Professor of Biology.

did.unittitle: Letter from Rene Laennec to a close friend and fellow physician, 1824, September 6

scopecontent.p: This letter was sent from Quimper, Brittany, the birthplace of Laennec who invented the stethoscope in 1819. The letter concerns Laennec's shortened stay in Brittany and invites his friend to dinner to discuss medicine with other friends. He refers to having not been able to meet his friend at Kerlouarnec, the Laennec family estate in Ploare, near Douarnenez.

did.unittitle: Letter from Carl Rokitansky to ?, 1861, 1862, 1869

scopecontent.p: Rokitansky is a famous pathologist born in Koniggratz, Bohemia. He studied in Prague and Vienna.

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, 1894 November 4

scopecontent.p: Banks writes of the rigors of life as a medical student at UVa.

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, 1895 February 5

scopecontent.p: Banks writes of his return trip and arriving in Basic at 6 A.M. (Basic City was an incorporated town in Augusta County that was eventually consolidated with Waynesboro.)

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, Genie, 1896 October 25

scopecontent.p: Banks writes from Baltimore, Maryland of his difficult exams in chemistry and materia medica.

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, Genie, 1896 November 8

scopecontent.p: Banks writes about his studies as well as a patient he is treating. He mentions McKinley's election and his desire to go to West Virginia, evidently as a doctor to work with miners.

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, Genie, 1896 November 15

scopecontent.p: Banks writes of having less respect for Republicans and "negroes" since the election. Says he will be the "white man's Dr."

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, Genie, 1896 November 22

scopecontent.p: Banks writes of medically helping a fellow boarder, praises the anatomy drill he got at the University of Virginia, says he is not worried about his studies and has been working hard.

did.unittitle: Letter from George W. Banks to his wife, 1897 March 14

scopecontent.p: Banks writes of studying and anticipates leaving the city soon. Mentions that people with syphilis go to hot springs to help the mercury soak into them.

did.unittitle: Letter from Mary and Dr. M. T. Reeder to Dr. and Mrs. George W. Banks, 1903 April 10

scopecontent.p: Dr. Reeder writes his cousin a sympathy letter on the occasion of the death of Banks' father who is Reeder's uncle.

did.unittitle: Check from the University of Virginia to R. C. Vandegrift & Son, 1887 September 1
Doctor's bill from H. C. Hubbard to Mr. Thomas W. Crowder, 1851

scopecontent.p: The account lists bill for medicine as well as visits. Names as well as relationships of the patients are given.

did.unittitle: Prescription for Dr. Samuel S. Masters, N.D.

scopecontent.p: The prescription is for rheumatism.

did.unittitle: Letter from H. Holt to Mrs. O. C. Billings, 1844 May 29

scopecontent.p: Holt gives medical advice for Mrs. Billings' sister. He sends pills to keep the bowels open and also advises drops. He suggests she use warm foot baths, or even better, warm hip baths; apply mustard poultices; and get non-fatiguing exercise.

did.unittitle: Class notes of M. B. Conrad, 1852-53

scopecontent.p: Conrad was from Virginia and a medical student at the University of Pennsylvania.

did.unittitle: Invitation to Dr. William Graham to attend operation of Dr. Hugh T. Nelson at the Charlottesville Dispensary Annex, 1898 October 25
Lecture notes on cholera and its treatment, 1831
Letter from Dr. Pennie to Mrs. T. L. Berney, 1827 May

scopecontent.p: Pennie congratulates Mrs. Berney on the birth of her baby and writes a prescription for a bowel complaint.

did.unittitle: Letter from G. N. Bliss to Dr. J. S. Davis (1824-85), 1865 November 7

scopecontent.p: Bliss was presumably a Union Officer in the Civil War. Davis treated him at Charlottesville Hospital and bliss thanks him for his kindness. The Rhode Island Historical Society has a collection of Civil War Military Records and includes the George N. Bliss Papers (MSS 298) and Soldiers and Sailors Historical Society Records (MSS 723). Bliss was a member of the First Regimental Rhode Island Cavalry.

did.unittitle: Sanitary Inspector's Report, Form K, 1864
Forty-first examination of the West Virginia Board of Examiners for Registered Nurses, 1927 October 27

scopecontent.p: The examination includes sections named pediatrics; practical; anatomy & physiology; bacteriology, hygiene, public health and sanitation; surgery & gynecology; obstetrics; history & ethics; medical nursing; dietetics; and materia medica, toxicology and chemistry

did.unittitle: Forty-second examination of the West Virginia Board of Examiners for Registered Nurses, 1928 April 16

scopecontent.p: The examination includes sections named obstetrics and gynecology; materia medica, therapeutics and toxicology; surgery; history & ethics; pediatrics; dietetics; medical nursing; and bacteriology, hygiene, chemistry, and public health

did.unittitle: Sanders family vaccination and physical examination records, 1920-22, 1928, 1953

scopecontent.p: Includes 1953 American National Red Cross membership card for Robert C. Sanders, a "Train Ticket to No-Diptheria town on the Health Road," and American Red Cross, Department of Nursing-Bureau of Public Health Nursing school inspection form for Pierce Sanders, Eliza Sanders, George Sanders, and Katy Sanders

did.unittitle: Postcard to Dr. J. E. Copeland; prescriptions by Dr. E. V. Copeland and Metcalf, N.D.

scopecontent.p: J. E. Copeland is thanked in the postcard. Dr. E V. Copeland's prescriptions show his address as Round Hill, Va. His pharmacist was H. T. Morrison & Co. also from Round Hill. A fifth prescription is signed metcalf and written on a paper with J. P. Wyer, Druggist, No. 4 Culpeper Street, Warrenton, Va.

did.unittitle: Fragment of daybook of Dr. Bartholomew Enderson, 1804, 1979
did.physdesc: 1 AD, 1 ANS, 1 TLS, 3 AN copies, 1 envelope

scopecontent.p: The daybook notes that Enderson died September 19, 1804 and was buried October 14.

did.unittitle: Daybook of Dr. J. E. Copeland, 1900-03

scopecontent.p: The daybook lists Copeland's patients, and sometimes their their ailments and his charges.

did.unittitle: Dr. William P. Braxton's lecture cards from medical courses at the University of Pennsylvania, 1836-37

scopecontent.p: The cards are for lectures in surgery, chemistry, theory and practice of medicine and clinical practice, materia medica and pharmacy, anatomy, women and children, institutes of medicine at the University of Pennsylvania. One card indicates he paid $10 for the use of the Pennsylvania Hospital and was entitled to the privilege of attending the practice thereof and the use of the library for one year. One card is from the Philadelphia Medical Institute and relates to winter examinations.

did.unittitle: Account book kept by [Dr.?] Robert Gamble, 1834-39

scopecontent.p: The account book mentions medicine given and medical services rendered as well as nonmedical transactions for labor, food or sundry items. The description of the account book is listed in a sale document which states that Charlottesville and spring Hill are mentioned as is Augusta County. The account book was purchased from Bookworm & Silverfish, box 516, Wytheville, Va. 24382 on 2/3/82 for $35.

did.unittitle: Letter from W. W. Keen to Dr. J. O. Skinner, 1927 January 25

scopecontent.p: The letter from Keen is to one of his students from 60 years earlier. He mentions having served in the Civil War and also encourages Skinner to read his book entitled "I Believe in God and in Evolution." Keen was a Professor of Surgery at the Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia. The letter was given in February 1984 as a gift from Nell Fuller of the Acquisitions Department at the CMHSL.

did.unittitle: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Doctor Morton, 1928 June 20

scopecontent.p: Kelly thanks Morton for his monograph on peptic ulcer and says Morton could be seen at the private hospital where Kelly works. The letter was given in February 1984 as a gift from Nell Fuller of the Acquisitions Department at the CMHSL.

did.unittitle: "Women Medical Students at UVA, Notes of Janet Coleman Kimbrough, M.D." 1978 March 15

scopecontent.p: This is Kimbrough's account of experiences as women in the Medical School at the time when women students were first admitted. Kimbrough was in the class of 1926. A number of professors are mentioned including R. Bennett Bean, Carl Speidel, Harvey E. Jordan, Harry T. Marshall, Gregory F. Lukianoff, Theodore Hough, James A. Waddell, John Staige Davis, "Burley" Watts, and James Carroll Flippin. Kimbrough describes courses in the various year, living arrangements and the search for internships.

did.unittitle: "Women Medical Students at UVA, Additions by Thelma Dunn, M.D." N.D.

scopecontent.p: This is Dean's account of experiences as women in the Medical School at the time when women students were first admitted. Dunn was in the class of 1926. She writes about Ruth Dean, the first woman to graduate from the School of Medicine at UVa. Professors that are mentioned include James A. Waddell, Harry T. Marshall, John Staige Davis, "Burley" Watts, R. Bennett Bean, Harvey E. Jordan, Theodore Hough, John S. Lawrence, Alfred Chanutin, James Carroll Flippin, Henry b. Mulholland, J. Edwin Wood, William H. Goowin, Isaac A. Bigger, John H. Neff, Allen F. Voshell, Royster, William E. Bray, D. C. Smith, William A. Lambeth, George B. Young, Paul B. Barringer, and Kenneth F. Maxcy. She also includes three stories about distinguished visitors to the University: William M. Thackeray, [Charles] Dickens, and Teddy Roosevelt.

did.unittitle: Letter from Thelma B. Dunn to Terry Thorkildson, "Women Medical Students at UVA," "Women Medical Students at UVA, Additions by Thelma Dunn, M.D.," and Notes of Janet Coleman Kimbrough, M.D. 1979 July 8 and N.D.
did.physdesc: 1 TLS 2pp., 2 TMs with AN 36pp. and 29pp., 1 AM 14 pp.

scopecontent.p: Dr. Themla Brumfield Dunn and Dr. Janet Coleman Kimbrough were requested by Mrs. Ferrell of the Medical Alumni Staff to write some account of their experiences as women in the Medical School at the time when women students were first admitted. Each of them first wrote an independent account of the events they remembered most vividly. They then got together and reduced the material to a brief account that the Medical Alumni News might wish to publish. These were given in February 1983 as a gift from Nell Fuller of the Acquisitions Department at the CMHSL.

did.unittitle: Documents related to the merger of the medical and nursing libraries, 1972 September-October

scopecontent.p: Participants in the process of library merger meetings include Wilhelm Moll, Nell Fuller, Thelma Moomaw, Ray Frantz, Kenneth Peterson, Phyllis Verhonick, and J. Robert Henderson. A letter is written from Ken Crispell to Wilhelm Moll.

did.unittitle: Letter from Christopher Bartels to Terry Thorkildson and letter from Terry Thorkildson to Christopher Bartels, 1988 June 6, 9

scopecontent.p: The letters regard a print of Walter Reed given by Dr. Robert Carey to the Mulholland Society to put in the renovated student lounge. The Mulholland Society wants to donate it to the library with the stipulation that it be publicly displayed.

did.unittitle: Letter from James R. Berry to Terry Thorkildson, 1983 October 31

scopecontent.p: Berry thanks Thorkildson for the loan of the portrait of Thomas Jefferson.

did.unittitle: Letter from Edmund Berkeley to John Patruno and letter from John Patruno to Julius Barclay, 1989 March 29, April 11

scopecontent.p: The letters concern books that Joan Echtenkamp identified in Special Collections that would be of interest to Health Sciences.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harriet S. Craghead to Linda Watson and letter from Linda Watson to Harriet S. Craghead, 1993, November 1, 4

scopecontent.p: The letters concern books that Joan Echtenkamp identified in Special Collections that would be of interest to Health Sciences.

did.unittitle: Convocation comments by William Bennett Bean, 1950 January

scopecontent.p: Bean's remarks were made at the opening convocation of the Colleges of Dentistry, Medicine and Pharmacy and the School of Nursing of the State University of Iowa, September 21, 1949.

did.unittitle: Invitation to the formal dedication of the Wilhelm Moll Rare Book and Medical History Room, 1981 May 14
University of Vriginia Medical Center 1961-1983 Department of Employee Health Services, 1985, January 30

scopecontent.p: In addition to being a handbook to Employee Health, the document includes material related to Nuzhet O. Atuk, Medical Director of the Employee Health Department from 1961-1983. A resolution honoring Atuk, copies of newletter articles, photos, and a letter regarding budgetary needs are included. Donated by Atuk on October 22, 2002.

did.unittitle: Nuzhet O. Atuk thank you from the McCoy family, N.D.

scopecontent.p: The Mccoy family thanks Atuk for his work on Von Hippel-Lindau disease. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: "Beginning of hemodialysis at the University of Virginia Hospital, 1959," N.D.

scopecontent.p: The hemodialysis team consisted of Drs. N. O. Atuk, Graham Henson, and Alfon Mosca plus two nurses, Margaret Jordan and Elise Michael. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Nuzhet O. Atuk to George E. Schreiner and reply, 1959 April

scopecontent.p: Atuk's letter gives details on his first dialysis of a patient at UVa. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from A. C. Vanella to Dr. N. O. Atuk, 1959 June 9

scopecontent.p: Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Parson to Nuzhet Atuk, 1959 November 2

scopecontent.p: Parson asks Atuk to write out the amount of money needed for the artificial kidney unit. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Nuzhet O. Atuk to William Parson, 1959 December 29

scopecontent.p: Atuk estimates costs needed to make an artificial kidney unit functional. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Robert T. Ulsh to William Parson, 1960 September 9

scopecontent.p: Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Nuzhet O. Atuk to Robert T. Ulsh, 1960 september 23

scopecontent.p: Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Floor plans for Dr. Atuk's room and kidney room, 1961 August 28

scopecontent.p: Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Grahame Henson to Nuzhet Atuk, 1995 July 31

scopecontent.p: Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Charles H. Gleason to Nuzhet [O. Atuk], 1998 October 10

scopecontent.p: Gleason remembers the excitement when UVa's first dialysis patient came out of her coma. Donated by Atuk on January 15, 2002.

did.unittitle: Letter from Florence Farrow to [Terry] Thorkildson enclosing a copy "The Cure of Cancer of the Breast by de Houppeville Translated from the French by Arthur S. Caron, M.D., 1981 October 10

scopecontent.p: Caron's translation is of part of Guillaume de Houppeville's book "La guerison du cancer au sein" printed in 1693. A Virgo record of the book is included.

did.unittitle: Correspondence between James S. Kennan and Mrs. Austin C. Embrey and Mrs. Leslie A. Faudree, 1989 June 6

scopecontent.p: The correspondence regards the gift of the diploma of James Clayton Reed (Walter Reed's older brother) to HC&S and the burial place of the mother of Walter Reed, Pharaba.

did.unittitle: Correspondence between Jefferson Randolph Kean and Joan Echtenkamp Klein, 1989 November

scopecontent.p: The correspondence regards the location of Kean's grandfather's diaries at Special Collections rather than HC&S.

did.unittitle: "The Daily Progress" University of Virginia Special Sesquicentennial Edition, 1969 April 13

scopecontent.p: The articles are about the University of Virginia Medical Center, School of Medicine and a brief history of the University of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Physician's recipe book, James Mills, 1822 Dec. 29 - 1824 Sept. 24

scopecontent.p: This little book has recipes for curing people with the following complaints: ague, cough, cold, ulcer, swollen glands, swollen legs, night sweats, cuts, sores, bruises, green sores, whooping cough, and erysipelas, as well as one for strengthening a person recovering from sickness. Also included are recipes for horses, sheep, and cows. It has directions for making bottled porter, beer, blacking, waterproof blacking, polish, and explosives such as squibs and fulminating silver. The accompanying thank you letter is a copy of one sent to the donor, Victoria Menzies.

did.unittitle: Recipe book for medicines, food, and miscellaneous items, 1841-1867

scopecontent.p: This book has directions for killing insects, planting fruit trees, making black ink and tallow candles, washing, and making or preserving the following food items: candy, cider, beef, ice cream, cabbage pickle, yeast, wine, mead, catsup, and toffee. Some of treatments for diseases included are: bronchitis, whooping cough, earache, stomach cramps, effects of laudanum, wounds, scrofula, asthma, ague, fever, cold, carbuncle, dysentery, bowel complaint, cholera, diarrhea, night sweats, rheumatism, vomiting, rattlesnake bite, mad dog bite, lockjaw, burns, cholic, erysipelas, croup, deafness, consumption, cancer, dropsy, piles, sore eyes, and quincy. Directions for the treatment of horses are included. The book is the gift of Miss Thomasia Goss, Comyn Hall, 601 Park St. Charlottesville, 22901, and was found in a trunk at the family home near Stoney Point. It was brought to the library by R. M. Hubbard, a retired UVa Engineering faculty member.

did.unittitle: Medical College of Virginia final examination: physical diagnosis, 1921 May 26
Letter soliciting support for expansion of UVa hospital from Vincent W. Archer and pamphlet with history and data from UVa and Virginia, [1945]
Memoirs Medical Alumni, Class of 1928 Univrsity of Virgiinia May 1978: Hubert B. Holsinger, 1978 May

scopecontent.p: Holsinger writes about his family, medical training, time with the 8th Evac, and later life.

did.unittitle: Letter from William H. Muller to Mark Ravitch, [pre 1964?]

scopecontent.p: Muller writes about his memories of Dr. Alfred Blalock. The letter was found in Dr. Muller's office by Wayne W. Ferguson.

did.unittitle: Floor plans of the Claude Moore Medical Education Building, 2009
UVa Internal Medicine: A Century of Excellence by Munsey S. Wheby, 2007, May 5
did.physdesc: 2 TMs (1 with AN)photocopies, 1 PowerPoint print out

scopecontent.p: Wheby gives the highlights of the Department of Medicine and includes pictures of buildings and prominent people in the department.

did.unittitle: Letter from George E. Bokinsky to All Department Heads and House Staff, 1947, October 31

scopecontent.p: Bokinsky, the Assistant Administrator for the UVa Hospital, informs the staff that the hospital is $300,000 in the red. He states that patients without satisfactory financial arrangements should not be referred for admission unless it is a life-or-death situation. Patients of questionable status are to be referred to the Social Service Department. Letter was found in a notebook belonging to Armistead Page Booker.

did.unittitle: "A Brief Autobiography for My Family" by Charles Shepherd Webb, 1932

scopecontent.p: Webb writes about his family, studies, work, and principal diseases that came under his care: pneumonia, obstetrics, typhoid fever, diphtheria, influenza, hook worm, and gallstones. Donated by Ann W. McDowell, March 2010.

did.unittitle: Charles Shepherd Webb, n.d.

scopecontent.p: Donated by Ann W. McDowell, March 2010.

did.unittitle: Charles Shepherd Webb: obituaries, November 28-29, 19--

scopecontent.p: Donated by Ann W. McDowell, March 2010.

did.unittitle: Correlation of the Physical and Vital Forces, n.d.

scopecontent.p: Donated by Ann W. McDowell, March 2010.

did.unittitle: Reprints by Charles Shepherd Webb, 1895-1930

scopecontent.p: "Mind and Body" reprinted from Virginia Medical Monthly, June 1895; "Infantile Diarrhea" reprinted from Mobile Medical and Surgical Journal, November 1905; "The Medical Treatment of Gall Stones" read before the Medical Society of Virginia, October 9-12, 1906; "Diphtheria" reprinted from the Old Dominion Journal of Medicine and Sugery, April 1910; "Pneumonia" reprinted from the Medical Record, May 27, 1911; "The Medical Profession and the Public" reprinted from The Charlotte Medical Journal, December 1914; "Puerperal Eclampsia" reprinted from Virginia Medical Monthly, April 1927; "Typhoid Fever" reprinted from Medical Review of Reviews, December 1927; "Some Cases" reprinted from Virginia Medical Monthly, January 1930; "My First Lesson in Anatomy" first published in the Religious Herald, Richmond, Va; "Jeffersonian Democracy, What Is It?" published in the Caroline Progress; "Organotherapy in Pelvic Imbalance" reprinted from The American Physician. Donated by Ann W. McDowell, March 2010.

did.physdesc: 5 Closing Exercises booklets bound together (1901-1905) and one which has come loose from the binding (1900) and 1ALS

scopecontent.p: Two of the University of Virginia Closing Exercises booklets have Micajah Boland's name written on them. Another has M. Boland written on it. Boland was a 1905 graduate of the UVa SOM. Boland (December 1876 or 1877 - May 1968) was a Captain in the U.S. Naval Medical Corps where he served from 1907 to 1937 and then returned in 1939 until 1945. The letter is from his daughter-in-law, Amanda Boland who donated the booklets to the UVa Medical Alumni Association. the Association gave them to HC&S in 2010.

did.unittitle: Letter fragments, November 28, 184[2?]

scopecontent.p: The letter was written from the University of Virginia. Much of the letter is missing, but the writer indicates that he is doing very well in his classes. Some phrases discernable are: breakfast by candlelight, always before sunrise, I find Medicine much more entertaining, professors, Daughters, go to the Episcopalian church, Ladies are few, chapters in the Bible. The UVa Medical Alumni Association gave the fragments to HC&S in 2010.

did.unittitle: Address to Medical Alumni on Alumni Day by Wilhelm Moll, May 7, 1976

scopecontent.p: Moll thanks the alumni for their support for the new library building that opened the previous month.

did.unittitle: Medical Book, ca. 1870s

scopecontent.p: The notebook contains a collection of remedies or cures (snake bite, rheumatism, neuralgia, diphtheria, facial paralysis); directions (how to take ink out of linen); and exercises, written in French and English. Pasted on top of these handwritten entries are clippings for cures (croup, cough, nail in the foot, toothache, consumption, burns, headaches, warts, baldness, etc.); directions (how to get rid of rats, crullers, renovate black silk, oyster soup, etc.); and animal care. One of the article clippings advertises the Prairie Farmer Annual for 1871 and includes an article about the Sprague Mower introduced in 1870. Donated by Kae Brown in 2010.

did.unittitle: Physical Therapy and No Smoking, 1977

scopecontent.p: The document is from the Admissions Department and advises patients to bring equipment from home if it will help them function independently. It also states that as of February 2, 1977, no form of cigarettes or tobacco will be for sale at the Medical Center. Patients are allowed to smoke only in their rooms. Visitors are not allowed to smoke.

did.unittitle: Iron Lung Exhibit guest book 2005-2006

scopecontent.p: The notebook was part of the Iron Lung Exhibit which was displayed in the Health Sciences Library. It provided a way for people to comment about the exhibit or share their personal stories.

did.unittitle: Operations by C.Bruce Morton II, MD while at the Mayo Clinic 1925 March 30 - 1927 September 24

scopecontent.p: The notebook is in two main sections. The first is called Experimental - Personal and has 6 parts, is handwritten, and contains 770 entries from March 30, 1925 to October 20, 1926. It lists operations and results. The second section is called Clinical - Assistant and consists of carbon copies, has 122 entries, and goes from July 3, 1927 to September 24, 1927. It includes where the patient came from, referring physician if there was one, the personnel involved in the patient's care, a diagnosis, treatment, and summary of the surgery.

did.unittitle: John R. Bookwalter, Interview with Justin Barr and State of Vermont Board of Medical Practice Proposed Decision and Order 2013 August 22, 2011 October 10

scopecontent.p: Bookwalter is the inventor of the Bookwalter retractor. Justin Barr interviewed Bookwalter because he is writing an article on the history of this surgical instrument. The Vermont Board of Medical Practice determined that Dr. Bookwalter engaged in unprofessional conduct and placed certain limits on his practice.

did.unittitle: Caricatures of University of Virginia faculty members by J. N. Pope '66 1966?
Case records of C B Morton 1927-1929

scopecontent.p: Includes typed abstracts of surgical cases from St. Mary's Hospital [Rochester, MN] from June 8, 1927 - August 15, 1927; Typed records of surgical cases from the University of Virginia from December 16, 1927- March 27, 1929; Handwritten 50 Case Records from the University of Virginia from December 16, 1927 - March 27, 1929.

did.unittitle: Diary of Bothwell Graham1934

scopecontent.p: Bothwell Graham III was a 1937 graduation of the UVa School of Medicine. His diary includes social engagements, what he was doing related to school, and some financial notations.

did.unittitle: "Students' Nursing Practice Record" - Marian Hosfeld1940 September 1

scopecontent.p: The Record is from the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and is signed by the Superintendent of Nurses, Lucy Masten. It lists over 150 duties, procedures, or treatments that Hosfeld was taught. Each item had a signature by her various supervisors. Several accompanying items are in the artifact collection: a nursing pin 15/16" in diameter, gold in color with red, white and blue paint, marked S of N Universitatis Pennsylvaniensis 1740 on the obverse, and engraved Marian Hosfeld Crosby R.N. on the reverse; three bobby pins; a circle pin 1 1/2"in diameter; and a 3 1/2" long straight hat pin.
